description: Least sum of 3 distinct nonzero squares in exactly n ways.
comments: The sequence is increasing only up to a(23) = 3461 > a(24) = 3449. - _M. F. Hasler_, Jan 25 2013
links: Zak Seidov and Donovan Johnson, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000 (first 200 terms from Zak Seidov)
Index entries for sequences related to sums of squares
example: a(1) = 1^2+2^2+3^2 = 1+4+9 = 14, which obviously is the smallest sum of 3 distinct nonzero squares and cannot be written otherwise as such a sum.a(2) = 1^2+5^2+6^2 = 1+25+36 = 2^2+3^2+7^2 = 4+9+49 = 62.
author: _David W. Wilson_
